text.0: the kine have come and brought good fortune let them rest in the cowpen and be happy near us.
text.1: here let them stay prolific manycoloured and yield through many morns their milk for indra.
text.2: indra aids him who offers sacrifice and gifts he takes not what is his and gives him more thereto.
text.3: increasing ever more and ever more his wealth he makes the pious dwell within unbroken bounds.
text.4: these are neer lost no robber ever injures them no evilminded foe attempts to harass them.
text.5: the master of the kine lives many a year with these the cows whereby he pours his gifts and serves the gods.
text.6: the charger with his dusty brow oertakes them not and never to the shambles do they take their way.
text.7: these cows the cattle of the pious worshipper roam over widespread pasture where no danger is.
text.8: to me the cows seem bhaga they seem indra they seem a portion of the firstpoured soma.
text.9: these present cows they o ye indra i long for indra with my heart and spirit.
text.10: o cows ye fatten een the worn and wasted and make the unlovely beautiful tolook on.
text.11: prosper my house ye with auspicious voices your power is glorified in our assemblies.
text.12: crop goodly pasturage and be prolific drink pure sweet water at good drinking places.
text.13: never be thief or sinful man your matter and may the dart of rudra still avoid you.
text.14: now let this close admixture be close intermigled with these cows.
text.15: mixt with the steers prolific flow and indra with thy hero might.
